org.mundo.rt
Class Message

java.lang.Object
  org.mundo.rt.Message
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<Message.Chunk>
public final class Message
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<Message.Chunk>

A message consists of a number of chunks. Chunks store the main message payload in different representations, optional (binary) attachments and additional information ("headers") e.g. for routing and transport services. A chunk is a tuple of (name, type, content). The content is stored in a TypedMap or in a Blob. A TypedMap contains active or passive object trees and Blobs contain e.g. binary attachments, like audio data.

MundoCore is based on the concept of a protocol heap rather than a protocol stack. Thus, services are permitted random-access to the message data structure and information stays available on all levels.

Typically, applications create Message objects from a TypedMap or an Object (to serialize). In this case, the only chunk that the application has to worry about is the following:

name type content Description
mainactive TypedMapContains the message payload

When the message is transported to a remote node, various services act on the contents of the message. A message received from a remote node might look like:

name type content Description
mainactive TypedMapContains the message payload as an active object tree. In most cases, this is the only chunk interesting to the application level.
mainpassive TypedMapContains the message payload as a passive object tree. Routing services create this chunk from the chunk containing the active representation.
erspassive TypedMapContains header information, like channel names and zone information, or control messages for the EventRoutingService.
rspassive TypedMapContains header information or control messages for the RoutingService.
iptspassive TypedMapContains header information or control messages for the IPTransportService.
allbinser BlobContains all other chunks of the message in a binary-serialized form. This chunk is created at the level of transport services.

Author:
Erwin Aitenbichler

Constructor Detail

Message

public Message()
Initializes an empty message.

Message

public Message(TypedMap map)
Initializes a new message from a TypedMap. This constructor creates a new chunk ("main", "active", map).

Parameters:
map - the map to put into the message.

Message

public Message(java.lang.String request,
               TypedMap map)
Deprecated. 

Initializes a message with the specified request and map. This constructor is deprecated, since it is no longer required to specify a SOAP request for ordinary messages. For compatibility, the specified request is written into the map with map.putString("request", request);.

Parameters:
request - the request.
map - the message payload.

map - the TypedMap containing a structured payload.

fromObject

public static Message fromObject(java.lang.Object obj)
Creates a new message from an Object. This named constructor creates a new chunk ("main", "active", map) and associates the object with the key object in map.

Parameters:
obj - the object to put into the message.

Overrides:
clone in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
a deep copy of this message; and null in case of an error.

shallowCopy

public Message shallowCopy()
Returns a shallow copy of this message. This operation does not copy anything of the content, only the protocol stack and processing state.

Returns:
a shallow copy of this message.

copyFrame

public Message copyFrame()
Returns a shallow copy of this message with an own chunks list and address chunk. New chunks can be added to the copy without side-effects on the original. The protocol stack and the current handler is also copied.

Returns:
a shallow copy of this message.

put

public void put(java.lang.String name,
                java.lang.String type,
                TypedMap map)
Creates or replaces a chunk. The method associates the specified name and type with the specified map. If a chunk with the same name and type already exists, the existing chunk is replaced.

Parameters:
name - the chunk name.
type - the chunk type.
map - the TypedMap containing a structured payload.

type - the chunk type.
Returns:

getBlob

public Blob getBlob(java.lang.String name)
Returns the content to which the specified chunk name is mapped. The method finds the first chunk with a matching name. The type is ignored.

Parameters:
name - the chunk name.
Returns:
the Blob object in the requested chunk; or null if no mapping for the specified name exists.

public TypedMap getMap()
Returns the main payload stored in the message. This is the content of the chunk ("main", "active", TypedMap).

Returns:
the content of the chunk ("main", "active", TypedMap); or null if the chunk does not exist.

the object stored in the message.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the chunk does not exist or the mapping for object does not exist.

getChunks

public TypedArray getChunks(java.lang.String typeFilter)
Returns all chunks matching the specified type.

Parameters:
typeFilter - the type name to use as filter.
Returns:
a TypedArray containing all chunks that match the specified type. The chunks are of class Message.Chunk.

iterator

public java.util.Iterator<Message.Chunk> iterator()
Returns an iterator over the chunks in this message.

Specified by:
iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<Message.Chunk>
Returns:
an iterator over all chunks of the message. The iterator provides objects of class Message.Chunk.

passivate

public void passivate()
               throws java.lang.Exception
Passivates the message. For each chunk with type active, a chunk with the same name and type passive is created. The content of the active chunk is passivated, i.e. externalized and converted to base types, and written to the corresponding passive chunk.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
TypedContainer.passivate(Object)

activate

public void activate()
              throws java.lang.Exception
Activates the message. For each chunk with type passive, a chunk with the same name and type active is created. The content of the passive chunk is activated, i.e. objects are instantiated from their external representations, and written to the active chunk.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
TypedContainer.activate(Object)
